title: Graham Norton reflects on the experience of being stabbed
text:
Graham has offered more insight into the terrible incident in 1989. (Picture: Rex)

Graham Norton has discussed his ‘formative’ experience of being stabbed and left for dead back in 1989.

The RuPaul’s Drag Race UK judge explained that almost dying after the attack completely changed his view on life.

‘The most formative thing that ever happened to me was getting stabbed in 1989,’ he tells The Observer in a new interview.

‘It gave me real perspective on life and what mattered.’

He furthermore explained that ‘before that I was at drama school, caught up in the search for success’.

‘I went back to drama school and people were slamming doors because of the roles they got and I was like: “Uh, I nearly died. I’m just really happy to be alive”,’ he said.

Michelle Visage, Alan Carr and Graham are judges on RuPaul’s Drag Race UK (Picture: BBC)

‘Now if I get worried about something, I can put it into perspective,’ he said.

Although best known as a chat show host, Graham is also known for his acting roles such as on Father Ted and Absolutely Fabulous.

The star’s latest comments come after The Graham Norton Show star discussed knife crime with The Mirror last month.

Graham’s amazing media career spans three decades (Picture: Getty)

He said: ‘I think it’s a lack of imagination in the end, that if you had the empathy, that level of imagination to think it through, that the person you’re stabbing could be a brother, friend, sister, mother or father, you wouldn’t do it.

‘Somehow people have been dehumanised.’

The TV veteran furthermore added: ‘[…] people are losing their lives and equally the kids stabbing people, their life is destroyed for nothing, for this stupid thing because they couldn’t get their heads around the consequences.’
